responses.content: We are reporting $134.4 billion in revenue and $7.7 billion in operating income, both of which exceeded the top end of our guidance ranges.
Our primary focus is on reducing our cost to serve within our operations network while continuing to invest in long-term strategic areas that enhance customer experiences.

We redesigned our fulfillment network from a national to a regionalized model, creating 8 interconnected regions, resulting in shorter travel distances, lower cost to serve, and faster delivery speeds.
More than half of Prime members' orders arrived the same day or next day across the top 60 largest U.S. metro areas, nearly 4x what was delivered by this point in 2019.
AWS remains the clear cloud infrastructure leader, with significant investments in Large Language Models and generative AI, positioning AWS as a leader in this space.

Our advertising services continue to grow robustly, driven by substantial investment in machine learning to ensure relevant ads for customers and expanding into video, live sports, audio, and grocery properties.
We have streamlined our investments to focus on areas with high potential impact, including streaming entertainment, low Earth orbit satellites with Kuiper, and healthcare.
Our grocery business, including Whole Foods and Amazon Fresh, continues to grow with new formats and strategies to optimize our physical store footprint and enhance our grocery offerings.
Amazon Business has reached a $35 billion annual gross sales run rate, with plans to grow it to a $100 billion-plus business by adding new features and services tailored to enterprise needs.
We anticipate significant AI-driven monetization in AWS, particularly with generative AI and large language models, expecting this impact to grow in the future.
We saw worldwide revenue of $134.4 billion, an increase of 11% year-over-year and above the top end of our guidance range.
Customers continue to trade down and seek value in their purchases, with healthy demand in everyday essentials and categories like beauty and health.
Advertising revenue remained strong, up 22% year-over-year, driven by performance-based advertising offerings.
Third-party unit mix increased to 60% during the quarter, the highest level we've ever seen, with good growth in the number of sellers and units sold per seller.

North America segment operating margins improved to 3.9%, an improvement of 620 basis points over the past 5 quarters. International segment margin loss improved to negative 3%, an improvement of 590 basis points over the last 3 quarters.

Free cash flow was positive and improved for the fourth consecutive quarter, with capital investments at $54 billion for the trailing 12-month period ended June 30, down from $61 billion the prior year.
For the full year 2023, we expect capital investments to be slightly more than $50 billion compared to $59 billion in 2022, with fulfillment and transportation CapEx down year-over-year.

questions: Can you give us a sense for how much of the optimization in the network with unit economics may have already been achieved versus how much more you think is left to go?
Can you leverage this reformulated network to help out with the grocery expansion, or will that be limited to the stores and the specialized automated facilities you're building out?
Amazon Business has been a couple of years since you've talked about that. How big of a priority is that for you, and what's the growth strategy to take it to $100 billion?
On AWS, given some of the commentary about moving beyond optimization and into new workloads, can you discuss the trends you're seeing versus what you had in the second quarter?
Can you talk about when you think AI monetization will start to flow into the AWS business? Is that in 2024 or the back half of the year?
When you take a step back, how much do you think about solving the grocery dynamic in the business to capitalize on it the way you want?
On North America retail margins, how should we think about the forward slope and investing in new initiatives like grocery and same-day delivery?
How high of an investment priority is improving your own retail and device network through more AI investments, potentially through logistics or AI-based agents?
As you lap optimizations and the macro-driven slowdown, how do you think about what normalized growth could look like for AWS in a better macro environment?
Can you provide clarity on how generative AI could change or affect your CapEx trajectory going forward?
